titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Attended the sale of Books without imprudence— Continued my Chronological Dissertation, and plodded over Petau. Walked an hour after dinner. Charles came home from School and went in the Evening to Countess Colombi’s to a children’s party— It being her daughter’s birth-day. He has had these three weeks a bad cough, and came home with it very troublesome this Evening— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us untill Midnight.

2. VII. Sleepless.— Charles’s cough was so bad that we kept him at home— My Time, the greatest part of the day was consequently taken up with him. I was at the sale of Books, and made several purchases. Walked an hour after dinner, and saw Venus set as Evening Star, 1/4 before Eight O’Clock. Proceeded in the arrangement of my Account-Books; which I hope to accomplish within the course of the present month.— Received from Mr Lewis the remittance from Mr Hazard.— Chess with Mr Smith.

3. VII.15. Charles is still so unwell with his Cough that we do not think it prudent to send him to school. I kept him employed all the early part of the day and had by consequence no other employment myself— My reading and writing are both interrupted by it— Finished this Morning the reading of the Old Testament, and began upon the Apocrypha. Received from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, tickets for the Exhibition at the St: Catherine’s Institution; to be to-morrow and the next day.— Attended the Sale of Books.— In the Evening, went with Mrs Adams to the Hall of the Philharmonic Society, where Handel’s Messiah was performed as a great Oratorio. The singers were from the German Theatre; but the performance was not good— We went early, but the Hall was so crowded that we had indifferent seats.

4. VI.45 We are still obliged to keep Charles at home from School; and this day to keep him confined to the warm chambers.— He reads to me three Chapters in the French Bible, and writes and copies his letters to his brothers. I attended the Sale at Grabit’s, though it was the day for sundry Articles, other than Books— In the Evening I continued the review of my Account Books—

5. VI:30. At nine O’Clock this morning I went to the Institution of St. Catherine, and attended the examinations of the Young Ladies who have completed their Education there, and are now about leaving the school. It was in all respects similar to that which I attended at the same place, three years ago, excepting that the examination in experimental philosophy was omitted, the teacher in that department having been long ill. The examinations in the German Language, Arithmetick, French Literature, Grammar, Logick, and Rhetorick were short— The most trying of the Exercises, was the translation of passages from a French Book, opened at Random by the visitors; and of which a few Sentences were read into Russian by several of the young Ladies. The music and the dancing took up at least three fourths of the time. The whole examination was finished about 2 in the afternoon— The works in Embroidery, artificial flowers, Carpet-work, and drawing were exposed as usual, and all done in the ordinary style of perfection— There was a Cold Collation served in one of the outer Halls— Of the two most distinguished of the young Ladies who exhibited, one was a french name, Mademoiselle Prévot de Lumian; and the other a German, Engelbach.— The first was most remarked for her beauty, and elegant accomplishments— The other, less handsome, was nearly as conspicuous in the literary exercises, and surpassed all the rest in the specimens of needle-work, tapestry, and embroidery— The crowd both in going and returning was impassible— The heat oppressive— No other of the foreign Ministers was there but Lord Walpole; I sat near Baron Klinkowström and had much Conversation with him— After I came home, I was too much disposed to idleness for serious employment— Mr Lewis was here about half an hour in the Evening— We finished it with a Rubber of Whist— Charles is yet confined to the chamber with his Cough.

6. VI. I have been several days quite unwell, without any precise complaint. This day I have had several feverish symptoms, and this Evening was totally incapable of application to any thing. In the morning I gave Charles his usual lessons; read Prayers for the second Sunday in Lent, and Massillon’s Sermon, upon les Ecueils de la Piété des Grands. His Doctrine that the Principles of Christianity apply to the Government of States as much as to the conduct of individuals is more congenial to my opinions than that of Paley who maintains the contrary— Massillon’s morals are discoloured by religious bigotry. Paley’s are infected with the poison of this world.— Paley seems to think Christianity was a Law made only to keep the peace between Shoemakers, Blacksmiths, and Lamplighters— Massillon sees no Christianity out of the Pale of the Church— Merciful God! in how many and how different shapes do the Passions and Vices of men disguise themselves to corrupt the purity of thy Word! Massillon and Paley are among the most distinguished and most virtuous defenders of the Christian Cause; yet Massillon incessantly preaches unrelenting Persecution to Heretics, and Paley curtails the Jurisdiction of Christianity, within narrower bounds than that of a Justice of Peace.

7. V:30. By daylight, and I hope to have no more use for morning lights this Season; nor ever again in this Country— Charles’s cough, though still very troublesome has so far abated that Mrs Adams took him this day to school. I believe his illness was in a great measure the cause of my own indisposition, which still very seriously affects me— I attended the sale of Books, but excepting several valuable works which I posses already nothing worth its place in a library was this day sold.— The weather was fine, and after dinner I walked to the Summer-Garden Gates. Saw Venus set about seven O’Clock.— As the twilight disappeared the Moon rose, and few of the Stars were to be seen— There was scarcely one in View that I did not know— The weather was still too Cold for stopping to examine the positions of any of them at leisure. After returning home I gave a couple of hours to my Account Books— There are so many errors in the Ledger that I know not whether the very attempt to revise them be not time lost— They almost all arise from my having undertaken to keep that Book in the commercial form; with a variety of Artificial Accounts; by which means many of the entries are debited and credited to other than the proper Accounts— The consequence is that my Ledger shews large balances due to me from some persons, and from me to others, when the truth the Accounts have long been settled and closed.— Since I left the United States, I scarcely know any thing of how my Accounts there stand.— I have been more than two years without receiving any from my Brother, whom I left my Agent and Attorney to transact all my business there— Doctor Galloway was here this morning but I did not see him.— Foot-Bath this Evening on going to bed.

8. VI. I received this morning an official Note from Mr Weydemeyer, and sent him the answer in the course of the day— Was at the sale of Books but made no purchase. The only Article of the Sale, which I should have secured was sold this day— It was the French History of China in 13. Volumes 4to. with an Atlas— It sold for double the price fixed in the Dictionaire Bibliographique— All valuable Books sell here at Auctions in that proportion with the prices of that Book— Dr: Galloway was here this morning, and prescribed for me a vial of Sacred Elixir— I am very unwell and have strong Symptoms of the Jaundice— A lassitude which has almost, but not yet quite suspended all my Industry— A listlessness which without extinguishing the love of life, affects the mind with the Sentiment that life is nothing worth. An oppression at the heart which without being positive pain is more distressing than pain itself— I still adhere however to my usual occupations— I feel nothing like the tediousness of time— Suffer nothing like Ennui— Time is too short for me, rather than too long. If the day were of forty-eight hours instead of twenty-four I could employ them all, so I had but eyes and hands, to read and write— I walked an hour after dinner and saw Venus set again; or rather saw her vanish about 1/4 of an hour above the horizon— She has but four days more to appear as Evening Star, for her lower conjunction with the Sun will be on the 12th. of this Month.— After coming home I continued the review of my Account-Books; but was soon called away by a visit from Mr Norman, who spent the rest of the Evening with us. He brought me a slip from an English Newspaper, containing President Madison’s Message to Congress of 7. December last, at the opening of the Session. An Extract from it had been published in the Russian and German St: Petersburg Gazette of this Morning.

9. VII:15. Dr: Galloway visited me again, and now pronounces decisively that I have the Jaundice. He also favours me with a prospect of its long continuance, and with a much deeper Shade He sat and conversed with me upon literary subjects upwards of an hour. Mr Montreal likewise paid me a Morning visit— I took a short walk before dinner, and another after dinner— The sky is yet
as clear as, I believe it can be in this Country, but I could not this Evening trace a sign of Venus, which I had seen so long and so distinctly last Evening— I went out this day about a quarter of an hour later than yesterday, but still with broad day-light. I think Venus has vanished from the naked eye, as Evening Star— We Spent the Evening at Back-gammon and whist; for I already recur to the Invalid’s privilege of Idleness.

10. V. The first part of the day I was better, and able to attend to my occupations— But from Noon was again quite unwell, and had all the Evening a troublesome head-ache— I went to the Auction, but excepting that, kept house the remainder of the day— At bed-time I took a warm Bath— Passed the Evening at Ombre— Mr Lewis sent me this morning a letter he had received from Mr Connell at Berlin dated 26. February— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard arrived there 21. Feby: and left Berlin again for Amsterdam the 24th. while they were there. Connell received a letter from Mr Curwen at Amsterdam, mentioning that he had seen and read a Message from President Madison to Congress declaring his acceptance of the proposal of the British Government to negotiate at Gothenburg.— Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard however had concluded to continue their Journey to Amsterdam.

11. Dr. Galloway was here, and thinks I have a prospect of a long and tedious illness. My own feelings lead to the same opinion— I am however less disqualified for occupation some days than others, and was employed great part of this day— The morning, from VII O’Clock when I rose untill Noon, with Chronology, and the Evening with my Account-Books— Attended at the Auction, and bought the French Translation of Josephus by Gillet— Paid for it about the price of a new Book.— Mr Lewis was here late in the Evening, but I was obliged to retire from the Company before 11 O’Clock.

12. VII:45. Morning visits from the General of the Jesuits Brzozovsky, and from Mr Montréal. The good old Father certainly has hopes of bringing me back within the Pale of the Church, for he seldom slips an opportunity of urging upon me the doctrine of adhering or returning to the faith of our forefathers— I told him that Principle would make us Jews or Heathens. He was ready enough with his answer. They are so thoroughly bred to controversy that they can never be surprized in argument. And as I wish to preserve the terms of good humour upon which we are, I forbear coming to the essential points upon which the Separation of the Churches ensued.— I told the Father General that I was seeking instruction from one of the ornaments of his order, and shewed him the Folio Volume on my Table— He thought it was Bellarmin— It was Petau— Yes—he said, Petau was a great man, and so were Suarez, and five or six others whose names have escaped me— I have not the pleasure of being acquainted with any of them.— I met Mr Montreal as I was walking out, and returned with him— He still continues in the state of agitation which the situation of his Country has excited, and endeavouring to disbelieve what cannot be doubted.— Attended about half an hour at the sale, and in the Evening after about two hours devoted to my Account Books, we passed the remainder at Cards, untill past Midnight.— This night was the lower conjunction of Venus with the Sun— But it was Cloudy.

13. VIII. Ill health is to me disorder of more than the Body— It produces disorder of the mind, and disorder in the distribution of my time— I gave Charles his lessons of reading, writing and arithmetic, and read Prayers for the third Sunday in lent. also Massillon’s Sermon for Good-Friday. On the obstacles to Truth in the Heart of the Great. Not much suited to the occasion; and not one of the best discourses.— In my walk before dinner I met Mr Hurd who is just recovering from his illness— And he has concluded to postpone his departure for some time longer. He says there are letters from England mentioning that an appointment had already been made there of a Minister to meet the American Ministers at Gothenburg.— By the Calendar, Venus should have been visible this morning and Mercury, after Sunset untill near 7 O’Clock; but I had no opportunity to ascertain it— Towards the close of the Evening the sky was clear.

14. V:30. I rose to see if it were possible to discover Venus as Morning star, but the sky was covered with Clouds.— Took Charles to School, and walked home. Attended at the Auction, but instead of purchasing, read in Le Beau’s Histoire du Bas Empire the Account of Photius the Patriarch of Constantinople in the ninth Century who commenced the schism between the Greek and Roman Churches— I had an idea that one of the causes of the separation was the time of celebrating Easter; but it was not. It was the Roman practise of using unleavened bread for the Eucharist—the doctrine that the Holy-Ghost proceeds from the Father and the Son (filioque) instead of from the father, by the Son; and fasting on Saturdays— Le Beau, who was a Roman Catholic gives a shocking account of Photius, though he acknowledges him to have been the greatest man of his age— I had a visit from Dr Galloway— Mr Smith dined with Mr Norman— Began the Evening with my Accounts, and finished it past Midnight, at Ombre.

15. VII:30. Attended at the sale, and examined further in Le Beau’s Histoire du Bas Empire. But Le Beau is a Roman Catholic— Small authority for Ecclesiastical History.— Mr Smith dined with Mr Lewis— At 9 this Evening I went to Grootten’s Baths on the Quay of the Neva, and took a warm water Bath. Mr Grootten himself, as my Landlord Mr Strugofshikoff told me yesterday, died last week very suddenly of a stroke of Apoplexy. I answered this morning a letter which I received yesterday from Mr Hurd— Continued my Chronological Dissertation, and the arrangement of my Accounts.

16. V:30. Had an indifferent Night after the Bath; and suffered severely, great part of it, with what Dr Galloway calls flying rhumatic pains— The symptoms of Jaundice which I had last week have partly disappeared. Lounged away two hours at the Sale. Proceeded with my Chronology— Evening visits from Count Maistre and Mr Lewis— The Count came to ask me to return the Books he lent me, and principally Petau’s Doctrine Temporum— The Count is a religious Man, a Roman Catholic, with all the prejudices of his sect. He is a great admirer of Malebranche, and has Locke and Condillac in horror. He thinks it a very sublime idea, of Malebranche’s, that God is the place in which Spirits exist, as space is the place of bodies— So differently are the minds of men constituted, that this comparison conveys to my understanding no idea at all.— It rather detracts from the idea I have of the Deity; because it takes away its most essential characteristic Intelligence— It draws closely to the absurdities of the Greek Philosophers who thought Water, Air, Fire, and what not, God— The Count was particularly harsh upon Locke, for his doctrine that we have no innate ideas— He insists that all our ideas are innate, and that a child can never learn any thing but what he knows already.— He expressed a very mean opinion of Locke’s genius, and said he was the origin of all the materialism of the 18th: Century— That Condillac was the corruptor of France— That Kant, the German Metaphysician, though an Atheist himself had gone far to demolish Locke’s pretence that experience was the source of our ideas, and that there was now wanting only a coup de pied to demolish such fellows as Locke and Condillac altogether— Mr Lewis made his visit very short— We played Cards after the Gentlemen were gone— Mrs Adams at the close of the Evening was very unwell.

17. VI:30. Called this morning upon Count Maistre, and returned him his Books— I should have wished to keep the Doctrina Temporum some weeks longer; but he had borrowed it for me, and was apprehensive of being called upon for it— I have found in it not only the account of the Gregorian Calendar that I wanted, but many other things of much curiosity and usefulness in Chronology. Had an hour’s Conversation with the Count on Topics of Literature, and we agreed better in our opinions than last Evening— Walked home, by the Fontanka and Neva Quays— After dinner I walked again with some hope of seeing Mercury, but I was disappointed— The rest of the Evening I was engaged with my Account-Books, and brought up the entries in the Ledger to the time when I left America. Another fortnight I hope will finish the work, and put my Books in all the order of which they are susceptible. The errors are fewer than I had expected, and may be corrected without much difficulty— The Evening was so clear and dark that I saw with my glass distinctly the four Stars of the sixth magnitudein the Centre of the Square at the Lion’s Tail—and I discovered the Cup under his paws.— Jupiter is very perceptibly drawing towards the Lion’s Heart.

18. VII. Morning visits from Mr Hurd and Mr Montreal— I gave Mr Hurd the answer to his letter, which I was just sealing up as he came in. Montreal is yet in the agitation of treacherous hopes, while every day and every hour brings more certainty to the anticipation of the inevitable Catastrophe— I went to the Sale and walked afterwards on the river Quay— Second walk after dinner, but no symptom of Mercury was to be seen. Mr Dobell and Mr Slade were here part of the Evening— I continued the revision of my Account-Books— Chess with Mr Smith untill past Midnight. Mrs Smith was taken ill at 2 O’Clock this Evening, and Mrs Reinike was with her the whole day— The weather is now fine, and moderate.— But from the 8th: of December, untill the 15th: of this Month, three Months and seven days the Academy’s Register has not once marked the Thermometer above 0. There never had before passed one entire Month since we have resided here without a sign of + at some time on the register. So that both the severity, and the continuance of the Cold has been greater this Winter than I had ever witnessed. On the 15th: at noon the Thermometer of the Academy is marked at +3; but the same Evening it is at -8:5 which in temperate climates would be felt as severe Cold— The Sun has great power in the middle of the day, but the sharpness of Winter returns at Night. As there has also been this Winter an extraordinary depth of Snow, the thaw makes the passage in the Streets unusually bad; and they will be likely to continue so for these six weeks.

19. V:30. At five minutes before eight O’Clock this morning, Mrs: Smith was delivered of a daughter— Mrs: Adams was up with her the whole Night. The morning was clear, and I rose to see if I could discover Venus as Morning Star. But although it is seven days after the conjunction I could see no trace of her— I was equally unsuccessful in the search of Mercury in the Evening. They are both too near the Sun, and are extinguished in his rays— I saw the Sun rise this morning, and it being within two days of the Equinox, I had an opportunity of marking the just Eastern point from my windows. The thaw had been yesterday so great in the Sun, as almost to flood the City— This morning the thermometer was -I attended at the auction— Charles came home from school. Made some further progress in my Chronological Dissertation, and with my Accounts.

20. VII:15 Mrs Adams was so unwell the whole of this day that we were obliged to omit the reading of prayers; but I read Massillon’s Sermon for Easter-day; on the Triumph of Religion— The Sermon like all the others in this collection of the Petit-Carême, has no reference, and scarcely an allusion to the festival upon which it was delivered— They are all Moral and Political Discourses, preached in the presence of Louis 15. when he was a boy, of nine years old— They are all upon the duties, the temptations, the Vices and the Virtues of the great— Whether Louis was of an age to understand them I know not— His life proved that if he did it was to little purpose. Instruction is lost upon fools— Mr Lewis sent me this morning a letter he had just received by the way of Holland, from Mr Diamond, in London; dated 15. February— It says that the Fair American Cartel had arrived had arrived at Liverpool, with letters from New-York to 22 January, and with Nathl: H. Strong as Consul at Gothenburg who was bearer of dispatches for Mr Bayard and me— That we together with Mr Henry Clay of Kentucky, and Mr Jonathan Russell had been appointed, to treat with the British Government, upon the invitation of Lord Castlereagh, at Gothenburg— That Messrs: Clay and Russell would not sail from the United States untill the 1st: of April, that I might have time to reach Gothenburg as soon as they— That Mr Strong was to embark in the next Packet for Holland or for Gothenburg, as he should find most advisable to meet me with diligence. Thus opens upon me a new prospect of futurity, and a new change in the Scenery of life— Upon this change it becomes me to implore the blessing of Heaven which can turn to good the most unpromising appearances, and above all, which can preserve integrity, and inspire Wisdom, whatever turn it may have destined that the Event should take.

21. V:30. It being the day of the Vernal Equinox, and by a rare accident fine weather, I observed from my Windows the rising Sun, and ascertained very precisely the Eastern point from them— The nights are still cold, and the Thermometer this morning was at -Walked with Charles to School, and gave notice to Mr Fishwick, that expecting shortly to leave this Country, I should probably take him from School at the close of this Quarter. Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit— Just as he came in I received a letter from Mr Hall at Gothenburg, with the Papers which I had enclosed by mistake to Mr Gray, and which I had written to Mr Hall requesting him to take out of the packet for Mr Gray and return to me.— I gave them to Mr: Montreal.— Attended at the Sale— Called to visit Mr De Tracy, and Mr De Castres, but they were not at their lodgings— Mr de Tracy came and passed part of the Evening with us. It appears that the allied armies in France have fallen back a little to concentrate their forces, and Tracy’s imagination has nearly annihilated them, allowing only to a few shattered remnants of them a refuge on this side the Rhine— There is in truth no Evidence that they have met with any serious loss; or any thing more than a slight check to one Corps of their right Wing— I rode out with Mrs: Adams this afternoon, and proceeded in the review of my Accounts; a work which is at last drawing towards a close.

22. VII:15. Dr: Galloway paid me a visit, and thinks the Jaundice has left me for the present— I still suffer however from the Rhumatism— Attended the sale again, and I think for the last time at this Auction.— Walked an hour after dinner, and then finished the posting of my Books. I have yet however to revise the Accounts in the Ledger, and to enter a Memorandum to correct the errors of mis-entries and omissions— I have also concluded upon another and a similar undertaking to occupy the leisure of the Evenings, during the next Month or six weeks. I shall probably not remain here beyond that time.

23. Received letters from Mr Bourne, and from the Willink’s and Van Staphorsts at Amsterdam, mentioning the acceptance by the American Government of the proposal from Lord Castlereagh to negotiate for Peace at Gothenburg.— Mr Bailey the English Consul, and his Lady, Dr: Beresford, Dr: Galloway, Mr Dobell, Messrs: Lewis, Slade, Norman, Hurd and Gould, dined with us; Charles came home from School, to-morrow being the day of the Emperor’s accession to the throne, and a Holiday— His cough has returned; and distressed me much this Evening.— Rose this morning at VI.

24. V:45. Anniversary of the Emperor Alexander’s accession to the throne. I was employed great part of the morning with Charles, and wasted the remainder by getting engaged with the first Volume of Sully’s Memoirs. This Book has undergone a singular Metamorphosis in the Edition of the Abbé de L’Ecluse, the only one I ever saw. The original Edition must be a totally different work.— I walked before and after dinner about an hour each time— Made a necessary Memorandum in my Ledger, which to be brought in order must be again revised— Began the arrangement of my Public Documents; and the Index to a 13th: Volume of American State-Papers.

25. VI:30. I took Charles to school in the Sledge, and walked over the River home. Continued my Chronological Dissertation, and reading Sully’s Memoirs. Also Crabbe’s Poems, lent us by Dr Beresford. Sully has taken such hold of me that I shall read him through, if I have time— Crabbe’s colours are gloomy; but his picture of human life is true— His Parish Register gives views of the Village very different from those of Goldsmith— He says that since the flood Auburn and Eden can no more be found— But there is a bright and a dark side to almost every thing in this world— Goldsmith’s picture shews only the sun-shine of the Village— Crabbe shews scarcely any thing but the shade. His characters are drawn with strong and distinct features— His Satire is sometimes as Caustic as that of Juvenal— Especially in the stories of Sir Richard Monday, and the Lady of the Manor— I have long doubted the soundness of the Morals involved in these dismal pictures of human existence— Crabbe is not quite so melancholy as Dr Johnson— Both of them are too much so. Life in all its forms, high and low, has great, numerous and exquisite enjoyments— It has also deep Afflictions, oppressive Cares, and some times overwhelming Calamities— To shew us nothing but its sorrows is to increase them; and it has no tendency to inspire us with Gratitude to that Good Being, by whose Bounty Life was given us as a Blessing.

26. VI. Made some little further progress in my Dissertation. Read the Second Book of Sully’s Memoirs. I read them more than twenty years ago in the English Translation, which is not a good one. I find them now more interesting; but want the original Edition to see what really belongs to Sully, and what to the abbé de L’Ecluse— Sully’s Education was imperfect, which I suppose was the reason why his Memoirs were so immethodical and confused, as to give rise to this transformation of them. He was presented in his 11th. year by his father to Henry 4. then King of Navarre, and attached himself to him from that time— It was just before Henry’s marriage and the massacre of St: Bartholomew, from which Sully escaped almost by a Miracle. From that time he abandoned all Study of the learned Languages, but applied himself assiduously to the Mathematics, History, and the Exercises that give strength and grace to the body. He was one of those beings so happily constituted by Nature that in reading his life it seems as if Virtue itself was a gift of God, so entire as to take away all responsibility from human action— His personal Courage had so much of rashness in it, in his Youth, that he must have perished on many occasions but for that unseen Spirit that protects the favourites of Heaven, which we call Fortune. His presence of Mind in the midst of danger, was as great and extraordinary as his valour; and saved him on many occasions when others must have fallen— He had from his childhood a Spirit of order and economy, which became one of the firmest Pillars of his greatness, yet blended with a liberality which on proper occasions made with cheerfulness the greatest pecuniary sacrifices— His controul over the Passion of Love was perhaps to complete; for he married by the advice of his Valet de chambre one Lady, while he was deeply in love with another; merely because the Lady whom he finally fixed upon, was richer and of higher rank than the other. He and his father were both believers in judicial Astrology;—and were convinced he was to be a great man, because it had been predicted— Indeed from the instances he gives of his own genius and discretion, in his infancy, the Astrologers needed no supernatural light to foretel his future greatness. There was a stubbornness of Resolution, and Perseverance in his Composition which I believe indispensable to all truly great characters; but it sometimes betrayed him into faults which he candidly acknowledges. There is one instance of it at the close of the first Book, which arose upon a point of false honour, in which he gave great offence to his Master, and deeply aggravated it by persisting in it, with what he himself terms insolent language. But his character and that of Henry 4. were so exactly adapted to each other that it was impossible for them to be permanently separated. Among the reflections which arise from the perusal of this Book, the mind can scarcely credit the strange and horrible picture of civil Society, which they exhibit— The rapid and continual alternations of Peace and War; the mixture of Debauchery and Devotion, of Marriage and Massacre, of festive entertainments, and pillaged Cities, Treaties made and broken every year, Treachery, Assassination, and Poison, all upon the pretext of Religion—bad as is this age, that I think was worse.

27. VI. Read prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and Massillon’s Sermon, upon the Virtues and Vices of the Great. It is in the Volume of the Petit-Carême; but it does not appear upon what day or what occasion it was preached. Gave Charles his lessons, and his Journal now answers for his writing Copies. Like my two elder boys, I find him a Child not easy to manage. Few children of his age have learnt so much, or had the mind so constantly and so variously exercised as he has— But he has the usual reluctance of children to learning, and a stubbornness of temper, which gives me some concern— Mrs: Bailey paid Mrs: Adams a visit this Morning— I walked an hour before dinner; but the thaw has made the Streets so bad, that from dinner time I kept house— The Evening was not profitably employed.

28. Took Charles to school in the sleigh, and walked home. I had risen at V:30. and employed the first morning hours with my Chronology. Had a morning visit from Mr Norman, who informed me of his intention of going to England. He assured me that he had formed no definitive commercial Connection with Mr Brown, and that if he should Mr Harris would have no interest in it, at least before the Peace— He also told me that from the time the American trade here had declined in 1812, untill within a week before Harris left this City, Meyer had treated Harris more like a Mooshik than a Gentleman. That he had on settling the accounts of their partnership thrown upon Harris all the debts in America— That Harris was much dissatisfied but took the accounts just as they were presented. That Meyer had cast off Harris with undissembled contempt, though he had made two millions of Rubles by the connection with him;—but that the last week before Harris went away, Meyer courted him again, and made him very handsome offers. Norman hinted that he thought it probable Meyer had succeeded in renewing the connection with Harris— He complained of Meyer’s conduct towards himself, and said Meyer was his Enemy— He also told me of his own ineffectual attempts to bring about a connection in business between Lewis and Harris, the failure of which I suppose is the principal cause of Lewis’s inveteracy now against Harris. Mr Norman brought me the Power which Harris left with him, as his Agent to transact the business of the Consulate, and asked me if I thought he could endorse it— As it contained no Power of Substitution, I thought he could not— He therefore left the Power with me— He waits for the arrival of the English Mails, of which there are now twenty-one due, and asked me to obtain a Courier’s Passport for him when he should be ready to go—which I promised him I would.— I read the third Book of Sully’s Memoirs, which attach my attention more and more— It is probably the most interesting Book of the work, by the variety and importance of the Events related in it—containing the Deaths of the Prince of Condé and of Catherine of Medicis— The assassinations of the Duke and Cardinal de Guise by Henry the 3d:— That of Henry the third himself by Jaques Clément—the final alliance of Henry 3d: and Henry 4th: against the Ligue, and the Battles of Arques and of Ivry; the whole interspersed with many excellent moral and political reflections. The particulars respecting Sully himself are also curious and important— The death of his wife— His house shut up against him, while she was dying, by his own brother; the dangers he escaped from, and the wounds he received at the Battle of Ivry; his four Prisoners who surrendered themselves to him alone, and in the most forlorn condition, his quarrel with d’Andelot a Son of Coligny’s for the Standard of the House of Guise, and the singular triumphal procession devised by his Ecuyer Maignan, are all incidents so striking that I am surprized at having no recollection of them from my former perusal of the book— After dinner I walked to the Summer-Garden Bridge— Met Mr de Tracy who walked with me—still feeding himself with flattering delusions though far reduced from the Confidence of his hopes, when here last week— Mr Lewis spent part of the Evening with us— I had not more than an hour of the Evening for employment.

29. VI. But I was obliged again to suspend my Chronology. Countess Colombi and her Sister Clémentine paid visits to our Ladies. I went to Grabit’s, to compare my minute of purchases at the sale with his Account, and found the Auction was not finished— His book agreed exactly with my minute, and I asked him to give a credit to General Senovert, and charge me for one Book which he had purchased and agreed to let me take— After a walk I returned home, and read the fourth Book of Sully’s Memoirs— It introduces a new Military Personage, and a great General, Alexander Farnese, Prince of Parma, opposed to Henry 4— This Book like the rest is full of instruction for a General and a Statesman; but the best Book in the world is like the Pipe that Hamlet offers to Rosenkrantz and Gildenstern— It will discourse excellent Music only to those who know how to govern the ventages. Sully tells his Story with candour, occasionally acknowledges his own faults and even though more gently those of his Master— One of Henry’s faults was the rashness with which he exposed his person in Action— A signal example of it is given in this Book,
at the affair which Henry used afterwards himself to call the error of Aumale. But I believe it impossible to acquire the reputation of Courage so indispensable to a military Commander, without committing many such errors. On that occasion Henry must have perished or at least been taken Prisoner, which to him and his cause would have been the same thing, but for an error of the opposite kind, excess of Prudence in the Prince of Parma, who thinking it impossible that Henry should expose himself as he was actually doing, suspected an Ambuscade, and lost the opportunity of taking or destroying his Enemy without danger, and without possibility of failure. Yet the Prince of Parma was personally brave, and Henry’s courage was tempered with sound Judgment and Discretion— He had Vigilance, Activity, and the natural faculty, improved by the Study of Caesar’s and Scipio’s lives, of seizing the critical moment, and moving with rapidity— Sixtus V said that he could not fail of conquering Mayenne, because the Béarnois spent less time in bed than the other did at table.— It was said of him too, that he wore out more Boots than shoes— Qualities, all suited to form a great character— His temper too seems to have been expressly adapted to his situation. It would seem as if Sully was the only man, who had ever any real attachment to his person— Between the Catholics and the Protestants, filled with all the Furies against one another, he was obliged to share his favours, and his armies and his Councils were composed of Elements more at War with themselves than with his adversaries.— His Catholic troops were ever ready to join his Enemies on account of his Religion; and the Protestants, for want of pay; while his financier a treacherous Catholic purposely kept his coffers drained, to produce the mutinies which might hasten his ruin. Then the private ends, the selfish projects, the jealousies and rivalries of his principal officers and adherents, the unsteadiness of some, the imbecility of others, and the profligacy of almost all were such perpetual obstacles to his success that one can scarcely believe it possible that he should have surmounted them. He told Sully after the Battle of Ivry, that untill then he had never been in a conditon to form Designs—that he had only felt Desires. His greatest, or rather his only vice was his Passion for Women; which was so excessive that in my Mind it casts a foul and indelible stain upon his character. It is indeed one of those Vices for which Mankind always had and ever will have great Indulgence. But to Men in such Stations, and placed under such Circumstances as his it is one of the most pernicious and fatal of Vices. Whether it is so Constitutional in some men and was in him, as to be uncontroulable I cannot undertake to say— But I can never consider the disgrace of a Goat, as the honour of a Man. On the other hand his Good-humour, his attachment to his friends, his humanity, his sacred regard to his word, are such admirable virtues, that it gives us a poor opinion of human nature to see how little they availed to gain him the affection even of his own partizans.— I rode out after dinner, and walked on the Quay’s with Mrs: Adams— Then worked a couple of hours in my chamber, at my Collection of State-Papers, and at ten closed the Evening.

30. V:30. Morning visit from Mr Montreal, who is very unwell with a nervous cough. He invited Mr: Smith and me to dine with his Uncle, this day and we went— We met there Messrs: de Tracy, de Castries, and de Chabannes, andall French Prisoners. I wrote a letter to my Mother, which with the dinner abroad took the time for reading and Sully remained closed on his shelf— In the Evening I could only finish the Second Volume of Crabbe’s Poems. This man’s Genius dwells too much in gloom. His Hall of Justice is a horrible Tale— Sir Eustace Gray is as bad— The Birth of Flattery is the only poem of the Collection that wears a smile.— That begins with two or three Spenserian Stanza’s, and then breaks off into the dull, monotonous couplet. It would have been much better to have persevered with the Stanza, throughout, and the Poem is so short that it could not have been very difficult.— But Crabbe’s poetical Powers, are not of a very high order; and like Walter Scott he appears unable to step out of his manner— Yet after all, if I were to class all the English Poets, there are not many that I should place above him. As a Satirist I think he would stand next to Young and before Churchill.

31. V.45. Received the Books I had purchased at the Auction; and among them I found three Volumes of the Miscellaneous Works of a Marquis d’Orbessan— I had never heard of this writer before, and his name is not to be found either in the Dictionnaire Historique, not in the Dictionnaire de Bibliographie— His fame has therefore not circulated very widely— In turning over the Pages of his Book, I found a Translation into French Prose, of Moore’s Fable of the Sparrow and the Dove, and a formal parallel, between it and La Fontaine’s two Pigeons. The comparison had occurred to me (v. Journal 29. April 1812.) but the Marquis prefers the French Fable, and I the English one. He perceives none of the faults in La Fontaine which struck me, and thinks that Moore’s Sparrow is not sufficiently punished, and that his Dove is too much of a scholar— There may be something in this last objection, but I think it a very slight error in comparison with La Fontaine’s Brother-Lovers, and his cowardly caution against travelling to see the world—
I read the 5th: Book of Sully’s Memoirs which is at least equally interesting with any of the preceding Books— It shews Sully as a great Statesman and Negotiator, as well as a military character— Many of the incidents have an air of Romance about them which raise an involuntary suspicion that there is a little colouring added to the narrative— Yet they are told with such particulars of detail, as have all the appearance of truth— Such is the account of his Mine, by which the Castle of Dreux was taken; and that of his obtaining all the Papers of Secret Negotiation between the Duke de Mayenne and Spain, and those of the third Party, whose project was to raise the Cardinal de Bourbon to the throne, and to get rid of Henry 4 by assassination— The characters of the Count de Soissons and of the Duke d’Epernon are well drawn— Those of Jeannin, Villeroy, the Abbé de Bellozane, and Cardinal Duperron sketched with a masterly hand. Sully ascribes entirely to his own Advice the king’s change of Religion, the Resolution for which was first adopted upon mere motives of policy— This is a very delicate point in the estimate of Henry’s character, and it is treated by Sully with great delicacy and circumspection— He says he believes that Henry’s conversion was in the last result sincere— That he finally came to the conclusion that the Catholic Faith was the safest— But in the controversial discussions between the divines of the two Sects, which he attended to fix his Creed, it was a tacit understanding on both sides that the Catholic Doctors should have the best of the Argument, and the Protestants had complaisantly consented to be defeated— Such State-jugglery in a matter of Religion is not very creditable to any of the parties, and very disgraceful to the Protestant Champions. It seems to me that both the Wisdom and the Virtue of Henry’s Apostasy are very equivocal. Had he firmly adhered to his first Faith, the Protestant Religion would have prevailed in France, and the Intolerance, the Persecutions; the Monkish Bigotry, and the perfidious Tyranny of Louis 14. would never have desolated that Country.— Yet it is hard to say that the measure was not indispensably necessary; when it was so considered by so sound a head and so firm a Heart as Sully; an inflexible Protestant himself; yet the first to advise his Master to that change, in which he could never be prevailed upon to follow the example.— One of the remarkable features of those times is the secrecy with which Henry was obliged to cover his Confidence in Sully, who for many years was his most intimate friend and Counsellor, without holding under him any office of apparent importance, and without being able to obtain the Government even of the Places, taken by himself— They were obliged to appear in public upon the coldest and most distant terms of reserve, and Sully was habitually introduced to the king’s Apartment in the Night, for the most important Consultations, to elude the Jealousy and Envy of the Catholic Nobles.— I walked before and after dinner, and wrote to the Secretary of State— Evening, engaged with the State-Papers.

Day. My rising hour has been something more approaching to regularity, this Month than the last; but my health has been more infirm— My occupations generally the same, but affected much by the state of my health— My Astronomical paroxysm has passed away, and my Mathematical propensity must be postponed to a more convenient Season.— The prospect of a wandering life has again opened upon me; with a view of cares and duties which will probably for many Months absorb all my time and faculties. Never have I had more urgent necessity to implore the Aid of the divine Spirit to enable me to discharge those duties with zeal, energy and fidelity. Never more need of the guiding hand of that being whose Inspiration is Wisdom and Virtue, and who disposes of all Events and controuls the Passions of Men and the course of Events— Merciful God! thou knowest all my wants— Provide for them as to thy infinite Wisdom shall seem meet, and whatever issue thy Providence has decreed to the purposes committed to my charge, grant that I may faithfully and entirely fulfill my duties to thee and to my Country!
